awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Rules of Life Program: Scientific Advancements and Future Opportunities
awd_abstract_narration:
Life sciences have become a core part of public policy and scientific solutions to address problems affecting nearly all aspects of society, including climate change, defense, public health and medicine, clean energy and energy independence, industry (i.e., the bioeconomy), agriculture, and sustainable development. Convergence of the life sciences with other scientific disciplines is a core enabler of advances across these sectors.  In 2016, the National Science Foundation (NSF) established a program on Understanding the Rules of Life (URoL) to identify generalizable rules that govern biological systems at micro- and macro-scales.  With support from this award, the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine Board on Life Sciences (NASEM) will conduct a retrospective analysis of the URoL program. For this analysis, the NASEM will interact with URoL principal investigators individually and in group settings to understand the program’s: a) achievements; b) integration of multi-disciplinary, systems-level approaches; c) broader implications for studying highly-complex systems, future scientific questions, and future societal needs; and d) the production of generalizable rules that apply to different fields and scales. The outcomes from these discussions will be include a proceedings, which will be peer reviewed and published through the established NASEM processes.
 
The NSF URoL Big Idea challenged scientists across numerous disciplines to identify rules that govern how biological systems function at various scales and complexities, and determine which of those rules are generalizable across systems. The assessment and synthesis activities supported by this award are designed explicitly to: a) identify rules of life that apply within systems of similar scale and complexity; b) determine which of those rules also apply to systems of differing scales and complexity; and c) capture the contributions from the multidisciplinary teams in URoL-funded research towards providing insight into successful methods for collaborating across scientific disciplines. NASEM has published several reports describing convergence of the life sciences with other disciplines, which will inform discussions with URoL investigators and the project outcomes. Critical themes from unstructured and structured discussions will be captured to ensure that the outcomes of the assessment are informative to NSF and the broader scientific community.  Furthermore, the knowledge gained about effective multidisciplinary research environments will enable future scientists to establish and lead multidisciplinary teams toward addressing future societal and scientific problems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Upon request by the BIO Directorate of the National Science Foundation, the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine’s Board on Life Sciences (BLS) conducted a retrospective analysis of the Understanding Rules of Life (URoL) Big Idea program. As part of this effort, the National Academies were asked to identify: a) individual and collective scientific advances toward achieving possible “rules of life” or principles that could help predict changes in biological systems; b) contributions of disciplinary convergence in driving scientific advances; c) approaches for integrating multidisciplinary and systems-analysis in research; d) broader implications of research conducted under the URoL program; e) possible future societal needs and scientific questions that may be addressed; and e) “rules of life” that may be generalizable across fields and scales. The National Academies’ project involved reviewing project abstracts funded under six URoL program calls (two focused on the microbiome, two on epigenetics, one on synthetic cells, and one on emergent networks), speaking with principal and co-principal investigators of URoL-funded projects, and conducting a workshop series, all of which were designed to achieve the stated objectives. The Proceedings from this work highlighted scientific advances that may be relevant across living systems and scales, approaches for fostering multidisciplinary research, and ways of building a scientific workforce that is equipped to conduct multidisciplinary research on complex problems. A brief booklet highlighting key themes from this work also was produced.

 

The analysis resulted in several scientific themes, several of which apply across scales and systems. Key themes identified from research involving epigenetics were the realization that some epigenetic changes are adaptive whereas others are not, stress modulates epigenetic status, epigenetic changes other than DNA methylation may prevail in some organisms, and epigenetic signals in one cell or organism may regulate transcription in another cell or organism. Key themes identified from research involving the microbiome were an acknowledgement that extant concepts of co-phylogeny and host switching may not reflect what actually happens in microbial communities, metabolomics may offer an avenue for predicting host disease and behavior, and the microbiome influences resilience to environmental disturbances. Key themes from research involving creation of synthetic cells were: a) ratios of membrane channels may be more important in propagating spikes than the absolute number of channels; b) large-scale mechanical behaviors may be more important than non-mechanical behaviors for healing physical damage; c) flexibility of cellular machinery may offer opportunities to create new kinds of materials; d) scaling laws apply across the tree of life; e) creation of synthetic cells without phospholipids in possible; and f) RNA folding is crucial for preventing its degradation in synthetic cells.  

 

In addition to scientific themes, the analysis identified strategies for enabling multidisciplinary research and training within multidisciplinary research environments. Strategies that were viewed by engaged principal and co-principal investigators as particularly helpful were: a) focusing research on problems rather than categorizing them as basic or applied can be a more helpful framework for approaching multidisciplinary research; b) co-developing products such as figures, papers, training materials, and presentations can help reduce collaboration barriers and establish teach dynamics and structures; c) defining team structures and roles clearly can enhance team science; d) ensuring effective communication and proximity, familiarity, and shared missions enhance multidisciplinary research; e) making education and training an integral part of multidisciplinary research can foster the next generation of researchers; f) supporting exchange among students, postdoctoral fellows, and others on the research team are effective means of training for multidisciplinary projects; and g) providing graduate student with opportunities to serve as liaisons among multidisciplinary teams and gain unique leadership and training experiences.

 

During the conversations with URoL principal and co-principal investigators, the National Academies identified some cross-cutting themes that could enhance current and future efforts toward advancing science to address future scientific and societal issues. These themes were: a) negative results can be as important as positive results in search of rules of life; b) possible rules and principles of life are beginning to emerge for particular biological systems; c) effective communication across groups could help to elucidate rules of life more broadly; and d) some rules may be translatable across systems such as the law of scalability, and studies examining multiple systems may help to illuminate underlying, cross-cutting principles.

 

These outcomes are described in future detail in the National Academies’ proceedings, Reflections on the National Science Foundation’s Understanding Rules of Life Program, which is available on the National Academies Press website (https://nap.nationalacademies.org/catalog/27020/reflections-on-the-national-science-foundations-understanding-the-rules-of-life-program).
